awd_titl_txt: Comparing Regional with Global Models in Atmospheric Science
awd_abstract_narration:
General Audience Summary 

The Principal Investigator on this project will collaborate with climate scientists at the National Center for Atmospheric Research to develop a framework to advance understanding and resolve conflict over the meanings of the concept, "value added," when comparing regional climate models to global models. The core questions are whether and, if so, how regional models add value to our understanding of climate with regards to global models. Regional models are some of the primary means available for modeling socially significant climate events such as floods, droughts, and fires, among other events; so, it is very important to understand their value. The investigator will situate herself in the climate science community, and use philosophical conceptual analysis, in collaboration with leading climate modelers, to develop an advanced framework. The proposed framework will refine and develop an existing framework based on a preliminary study that she conducted.  She will then use the advanced framework to analyze ongoing debates in detail, and in doing so to define and develop the various meanings of "value added." She will publish articles in both climate science and philosophical journals with these new frameworks and analyses, clarifying where there is now mostly confusion. She will also apply this knowledge towards the publication of one or more articles for the general public, urging clarity about climate issues and their impact on our daily lives.

Technical Summary 

The proposed project has the capacity to advance philosophical knowledge concerning the concept of "value added," of which there is presently none, despite its cutting edge role in climate modeling. Knowledge in climate science concerning this concept will be amplified through the introduction of an advanced analytical framework and its application to a variety of debates on the topic of "value added." The climate community currently uses that term in conflicting ways in heated discussions, with little awareness of its ambiguities. The PI's aim is to cool down these conflicts by analyzing the various meanings of the term involved in the various debates she will examine, clarifying the mismatch of usage of the terms, and through the use of the advanced framework developed through this project, urging more uniformity of meaning and deeper understanding of the various issues engaged in "value added." The investigator's collaboration with her climate scientist co-authors will reach a wide variety of climate modelers, nearly all of who are involved in modeling impacts of climate change on society. Her clarification and analysis of the concept of "value added," central as it is to the value of regional climate models and the funding and support thereof, should have a serious impact on those who inform us about droughts, floods, forest fires, and other climate consequences.

Project Title: Comparing Regional with Global Models in Atmospheric Science

This project involved having the Principle Investigator (PI) travel to the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) in Boulder, CO, in July 2016 for six weeks, and in Spring 2017, for one month, to study with climate scientists specifically involved in regional and global modeling. There was also funding for a trip to the American Geophysical Union meeting where the PI organizes a session on model interpretation and philosophy of science. The PI also traveled to Exeter, UK, to meet with members of the Met Office there, to discuss the accuracy and applicability of regional climate models and their uses in extreme event attribution. During the summer period the PI had the assistance of a graduate student for literature searches and later, manuscript review. The PI attended brown bag seminars, scheduled lectures, conferences, and colloquia at NCAR related to both global and regional climate modeling. She also consulted with a variety of researchers involved in statistical analysis of models, including Doug Nychka, the organizational head of IMAGe, as well as Claudia Tebaldi, both at NCAR. Her main contacts in the modeling community at NCAR worked in Linda Mearns’ group, including Melissa Bukovsky and Seth McGinnis, both of whom work on both regional and global modeling and analysis.

 

As a philosopher of science, the PI attempted to analyze the relationships between the global and regional models, and to detect why there was conflict among climate scientists about a key question: do regional climate models “add value”? The meaning of the term “added value” was at the heart of the issue, and the PI used her philosophical tools to analyze central conflicts among climate scientists about this term. On her analysis, several of the areas of conflict occurred because the relevant parties had different goals and were seeking to use models for different purposes.

 

Thus, when they asked whether a regional model “added value”, they were really asking whether the model could answer their very specific question about the climate, such as, “how much does the mean global temperature increase as a result of climate change in this area?”, which requires regional models to do something they’re not used to measuring. Another group might, however, be asking an entirely different question when they ask about “added value”, such as “How much do the extremes in precipitation change in this region with climate change?”, a question that can be answered with regional climate models under their ordinary usage. The result is that regional models would add value in the second case, but not so much in the first, just because they would be good at answering the second research question, and not be well-designed to answer the first research question. This is a key conclusion of the investigation; there is cross-talk that is self-defeating about “added value,” due to its use in distinct contexts. More agreement would arise if practitioners were clearer about which exact research question they were pursuing, and how well they thought the regional modelers could help. My climate science colleagues and I have written a paper, “An analysis of the disagreement about Added Value by Regional Climate Models,” by Elisabeth A. Lloyd, Melissa Bukovsky, and Linda O. Mearns, submitted for journal review, analyzing and offering some solutions to the debates which should aid not just the climate modelers, but also the users of regional climate models such as regional and local planners in charge of impacts such as water use, drought planning, forest fire preparation and prevention, and land management. I have also composed an OpEd piece, under the guidance of the OpEd Project training program, which has yet to be accepted for publication, on extreme events and regional climate models, for the general public.            

 

A further two papers were written under the auspices of this grant, on the applications of regional and global climate models to extreme event attribution, and a methodological debate occurring within the climate community. These issues were discussed with the scientists at the Met Office in Exeter and at Oxford. This debate involved also social values and the preferences for underpreparedness and overpreparedness and its costs. The two papers are: “Assessing climate change impacts on extreme weather events: the case for an alternative (Bayesian) approach”, by Michael E. Mann, Elisabeth A. Lloyd, and Naomi Oreskes, Climatic Change (2017) 144:131-142; and “Climate change attribution: When is it appropriate to change approaches?” in Earth’s Future February 13, 2018 online, 1-16.
